title: Recent Work
text: Here is a sampling of some of the things I’ve been working on.

title: Recent Work
text:
Mobile BBS Flux Tower






Me working on setting up the flux tower







The finished flux tower





In early summer 2023 I designed and deployed a light-weight EC system mounted on a telescoping tripod to measure CO2 fluxes in stand of lodgepole pine seedlings in Burns Bog that sprouted following a fire in 2016.

title: Recent Work
text:
Flux Footprint Mapping
I’ve developed a python based tool for creating flux footprints web maps using the Kljun et al. (2015) flux footprint model. The maps for our field sites are shown in the image below. You can click the list sites on the left to zoom to site and see the flux footprint climatology for the site. The tool also has the capability to include a vegetation map for the site to better estimate the flux contribution by different source/sink area

I’m still working on preparing/documenting the code for broader distribution. I’ll post a link here when its ready :D



  <p>Your browser does not support iframes.</p>

View Slides in New Tab

title: Recent Work
text:
Arctic Carbon Fluxes






The EC station I installed at Fish Island, NWD in 2017







Collecting data from the EC station I operated at Illisarvik, NWT in 2016





For my PhD research, I studied carbon fluxes in wetland ecosystem in the Mackenzie Delta Region. I conducted two field seasons of research. In 2016 I worked at Illisarvik, an artificially drained thermokarst lake on Richard’s Island, NWT. Then in 2017 I installed an EC station at Fish Island, a low-center polygon ecosystem in the Mackenzie River Delta.

title: Recent Work
text:
Courses
From Summer 2020 to Summer 2023, I taught Geographic Information Science. You can find the website for the most recent term of the course here. As of Fall 2023, I am teaching “Atmospheric Environments”, which is an introductory level course focusing on the dynamics governing the weather and climate. The course website can be found here. In Winter 2023, I will be teaching “Microscale Weather and Climate”, an upper level course focusing on ecosystem scale weather and climate dynamics and how they influence the global climate system.

title: Recent Work
text:
Evaluations
All of my available teaching evaluations are posted here. Thus far these evaluations only cover GEOS 270 (Geographic Information Science).

The wording of the evaluation questions has changed between terms, but one key question has not changed: Considering everything, how would you rate this course? The chart and table below summarize my student’s responses.

title: Make your own website!
text:
This webpage was created using Quarto and is hosted using Github Pages. Quarto is an open source scientific writing package that helps you write articles, create presentations, and publish websites. It supports integration with Python and R, and can render .pdf, .docx, .html, .pptx files and multiple other types of documents.
If you want to make your own, the first step is to download and install Quarto. It can be run in RStudio or VSCode (along with other apps). To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
To host a personal website you need to create a github repository using this format: User-Name.github.io

This isn’t necessary to host a regular webpage with github, only if you want to make a “homepage” for yourself. i.e., the repo for this site is: https://github.com/June-Skeeter/june-skeeter.github.io, so when the page is rendered it shows up as https://june-skeeter.github.io/
You can use other naming conventions if you don’t need this. i.e., the here is a repo hosted on the micromet github: https://github.com/ubc-micromet/FieldSiteMaps, and the corresponding github page address is https://ubc-micromet.github.io/FieldSiteMaps/

title: About Me
text:
Name: Dr. June Skeeter
Pronouns: They/Them/Theirs
Email: june.skeeter@ubc.ca
Hi! I’m Dr. June Skeeter. I am a micrometeorologist and spatial data scientist. I am currently working at the University of British Columbia as a postdoctoral researcher and sessional instructor. My principal area of focus is the processes governing ecosystem-atmosphere exchange of greenhouse gasses such as carbon dioxide and methane; and the resulting feedbacks that influence the global climate system.






I’m an avid programmer I am fluent in Python and functionally proficient in a number of other languages including JavaScript, R, and Matlab. I love making maps and enjoy creating interactive, web-based applications for research and education. I prefer to work with open source options whenever possible because accessibility of information, transparency in data analysis, and minimizing barriers to access are central to my research and pedagogical philosophies.

I created this website to highlight some of my work and provide a template others can use to make their own website!

If you’d like to use this template, clone the repo and try it out for yourself!

title: AboutMe
text:
This webpage was created using Quarto and is hosted using Github Pages. Quarto is an open source scientific writing package that helps you write articles, create presentations, and publish websites. It supports integration with Python and R, and can render .pdf, .docx, .html, .pptx files and multiple other types of documents.
If you want to make your own, the first step is to download and install Quarto. It can be run in RStudio or VSCode (along with other apps). To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
To host a personal website you need to create a github repository using this format:

User-Name.github.io
This isn’t necessary to host a regular webpage with github, only if you want to make a “homepage” for yourself. i.e., the repo for this site is: https://github.com/June-Skeeter/june-skeeter.github.io, so when the page is rendered it shows up as https://june-skeeter.github.io/
You can use other naming conventions if you don’t need this. i.e., the here is a repo hosted on the micromet github: https://github.com/ubc-micromet/FieldSiteMaps, and the corresponding github page address is https://ubc-micromet.github.io/FieldSiteMaps/

This should mostly work as is, provided you install Quarto. To render the .pdf version of the CV template you will also need LaTeX installed. I use the XeTeX engine which I you can find here; you can also try installing “TinyTex” instead directly through Quarto by typing this command in the termina:
’‘’console quarto install tinytex’’’
This template also uses the quarto package Section Bibliographies Filter - I’ve included it in this repo (under _extensions) because I’ve altered it slightly from its orignal format. It should work as is? But you may need to install it with first then replace with the updated version.
Don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any questions.
